narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The learning format was a brief introductory lecture at the beginning of class to help situate students contextually. After that, the instructor then opened up the floor for organic, natural dialogue.
The course was a live virtual lecture.

This course was conducted live via Zoom, usually with a brief lecture and more extended discussion period when student would comment on the course readings. Virtual breakout rooms were also used for some discussions.

Mixture of student/teacher-led discussions, with the class often beginning with a presentation introducing the topic of the day. Supplemental material included documentary clips, Youtube music videos/commercials, and a guest speaker.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We surveyed a bunch of different thematic areas through case studies all around SEAsia, so I gained both general knowledge about many different topics and in-depth understanding of the themes and countries I chose to write my midterm and final paper on. This class also exposed me to so many different types of "academic writing" helping me find my own style and practice analytical reading.
I got an overview of Southeast Asian culture and the overall study of SE Asia. The class gave me a look into the diversity and complexity of the region.

Upon completing this course, I have a better understanding of the diverse complexity of the Southeast Asia region. Although the term "Southeast Asia" itself is constructed terminology, I learned that "Southeast Asia" is very much real in the minds of both scholars working in the region and local governments interacting with one another. Consistent writing exercises throughout the course also helped to sharpen my analytical thinking skills and have made me a better writer.

I came in with zero experience in anthropology, but I have learned so much about Southeast Asia (its cultures, kinship structures, religion, etc). Prof. Harms and our TA, Jill, gives great advice on writing style, and my writing skills has definitely improved!
How to carefully and thoroughly read, synthesize, and understand anthropological literature. How to write anthropological literature.

An excellent survey on the anthropology of Southeast Asia, particularly from the perspective of the modes of modernization and the myriad of different things it can mean to the oppressor and the oppressed.

This course gave me a fascinating glimpse into some of the social and cultural forms and currents in contemporary Southeast Asia. Primarily through readings and in-class discussions, we learned about the history of "Southeast Asia" itself as a conceptual region, tangible elements such as geography and environment as well as the urban landscape, ideas and expressions of "tradition" and how they interact with ideas and expressions of "modernity," history, politics, migration, music, and many more aspects of life and society. Delving into such a wide and rich area of study, I learned more about the complexity of Southeast Asia and how numerous perspectives can be used to  create a fuller picture of subjects large and small.
Critical thinking, Southeast Asain studies, academic writing

I learned about modern Southeast Asia and I learned about the field of cultural anthropology. This class was the most intellectually provoking class I had this semester. It makes you rethink your understanding of ethnicity, rurality, urban development, beauty, etc.

Generally, I learned how to critically analyze anthropological texts, most notably by gaining vocabulary to understand concepts surrounding capitalism, society, class, and culture. More specifically, I learned about the complexities that go into respective areas in Southeast Asia, and how to observe and understand from the perspective of a Western education.  

Via zoom, I learned how to advocate more for my needs in understanding the material and also reaching out for help when I needed.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: AMAZING professor and TF Jill Tan who created an incredibly warm and supportive community one of the best I've been in during these two zoom semesters. Generally manageable reading, especially after Prof. Harms's disclaimer at the start of the semester about his expectations of how deeply he wanted us to read each text (approx. 45 minutes per text, for about 3 texts per lessons). I also really enjoyed the the collaborative way peers, our TF, and our professor worked together to build on ideas or make references to other ideas/case studies/texts that could be useful if you were particularly interested in a specific topic. Weaknesses: while the inclusiveness of Prof. Harms's admission into the seminar built a very diverse group of students, the class felt a bit big sometimes and it could be hard to feel engaged in discussions if certain days were dominated by specific students or texts. Perhaps if there wasn't a professor preference for which text to begin with, students could provide input the night before class on the texts they're interested in so the discussion can be more balanced!
The course is very interesting and Prof. Harms always takes student concerns into account. It has a great organizational structure. I do wish we spent more time on some lesser known countries.

One strength of the course was the wide selection of readings that examined a particular trend or historical process through a specific country case example. Perhaps one thing that could be improved would be to include more readings on the countries that had less attention. For example, except for the week where our class discussed the Rohingya crisis and the Cambodian Genocide, I did not notice any other readings on Myanmar or Cambodia in any of the other weeks. I also would have liked to have been exposed to more readings on Laos and Timor Leste. 

Another strength of the course was that the "mini lecture then discussion" format of the course allowed for active student participation. 

Perhaps another area of improvement would be considering how the regions of "East Asia" and "South Asia" have interacted and continue to engage with what we call "Southeast Asia." This could be especially salient in how either of those two aforementioned regions have contributed to Southeast Asian modernity. Maybe these connections were implied in some of the readings, but perhaps they could have been made more explicit.
Professor Harms and TA Jill Tan were both fantastic! God bless them.

Strengths: managable workload, engaging discussions, amazing professor/TA/classmates and the course was well-structured.

Weaknesses: We got to sample one aspect of Southeast Asia each week, so we learned many things about Southeast Asia (culture, kinship, religions, etc) over the semester. However, we did not have the time to study one topic in-depth and look into smaller countries in Southeast Asia such as East Timor and Brunei.

The main strengths of the course were its varied approaches to subject matter, often using sources which seemed very specific or idiosyncratic to draw out really interesting ideas and information, and its focus on student discussion of readings. Course assignments were also well designed to promote further exploration, and didn't feel stressful or arbitrary. A potential weakness of the course was that the balance between student discussion and lecture occasionally felt like it underemphasized the latter. Some readings could also be especially heavy for certain weeks, without much corresponding time spent on them in class. I think that a more regular period of time could be given to structured lectures, and that more choice could be introduced into the weekly readings.
Very engaging and supportive professors, could have more engaging material during seminars

I loved everything about the course. Perhaps the strongest part of the course was the knowledge shared between the Professor and the TA, and their ability to 'read the room' and gauge student engagement and adjust accordingly. By doing this, it seemed that the class was able to invest more into the material provided.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The accommodations made for students undergoing grief and hardship during the class has been incredibly generous and I am personally thankful for both Prof Harms's and Jill's support. Scheduling virtual office hours was also very easy and accessible in comparison to other classes. In terms of things to be improved, perhaps Prof. Harms could share his presentations or lecture notes for the more Leminar style classes at the start because it could feel a bit like drinking from a fire hose at times.

Prof Harms encouraged participation in class and often used the share screen function to share media that helped our learning. We often used breakout rooms for discussion which helped me to get feedback on my ideas in a smaller setting.
N/A
excellent adaptation to the current environment, thanks!

All Covid adjustments worked very effectively. This would have been such a fantastic course in-person which I'm sad to miss out on, but even in the online setting it was very engaging and I loved the course.

I thought that the modifications of the class throughout the term was beneficial, and Prof. Harms really showed how much he cares about the wellbeing of his students by doing this. We still managed to learn a lot during the class, showing that you don't need to read a book a week to start learning about modernization in the Global South.

The use of breakout rooms in the class to help further student discussions worked well, and could have been expanded upon even further. I think that more time could also be spent using virtual activities and breakout rooms to build a stronger sense of connection between students, getting to know each other more personally outside of reading discussions. Screen sharing technology was also used well in this course to share videos and other material, something which I think could also be expanded upon so long as the technology enables it to be done smoothly without lag or distortion.

Because of the small class size, this was one of the most engaging classes I took this semester. I really enjoyed the range of mediums used to warm us up to begin the class, from the google earth exercises to the music videos we got to choose and watch. No real complaints since both the Prof. and the TA were so responsive and willing to meet in the case that problems inherit in online learning (difficulty speaking up in class for example), to explain or help.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 10000% recommend this course, especially if the student is interested in SEAsia or anthropology as a discipline. Honestly, getting to learn under Prof. Harms and within the student community he creates makes the entire class worth it. You really feel excited to be a scholar, often times reading people who are doing amazing work right now (sometimes even at Yale!). This class was the first time I really felt like I had an academic home at Yale, even though the pandemic semester really put a damper on things. I will be returning to many of the texts that we read in the future, which is definitely a testament to the quality of the syllabus and discussions we had.
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in regional studies, SE Asia, or just wants a great class with an amazing instructor.

I would highly recommend this course because Southeast Asia is a very dynamic region, so there's a lot to learn from the beautiful diversity of the people and cultures. Given the extended history of contact too with other adjacent regions like South Asia and East Asia, Southeast Asia is a useful region to examine overarching themes and/or other historical trends.
Yes!
I would recommend this class to any students even remotely interested in learning more about Southeast Asian culture.
Absolutely! I love this course. It is very rewarding and teaches me to look at things in an anthropological len. It have completely shaped the way I view people and social issues!
Yes. There is a decent bit of reading and occasional writing assignments, but this was such an interesting class and Professor Harms is one of the best professors I've had at Yale.
Yes absolutely. Prepare to come in and be challenged on your ideas of post colonization, kinship, etc.!!!
Yes, Professor Harms is great and if you want to learn more about SE Asia or anthropology then it's a great class.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another Yale student. It's a great course with fascinating insights into Southeast Asian society, culture, and life at various different levels. Its focus on the interplay between "tradition" and "modernity" makes it all the more relevant to understanding the human experience in general. I would go into this course with an open mind and a readiness and excitement to learn about and to begin to explore a variety of people and places in all their complexity and depth.
Yes!! Take this class, it was life-changing for me.

I would definitely recommend this course for two reasons: firstly, the content of the course is incredible and the teaching staff is incredibly dedicated to making you learn. The students who fall into this class are also super interesting and have so much to teach you as well. Secondly, the online application of this class was done beautifully, with so much care and intention put into it. In times of COVID-19, that part was super important since it provided a space that not only nurtured learning, but also felt like a community.
Yes! Professor Harms is great and the material is interesting.
